summary: This document is a chain of emails from January 2020 among U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) staff regarding travel arrangements for a team conducting interviews in Stockholm, Sweden, as part of the Epstein investigation (2018R01618). The emails detail logistical issues, cost concerns, and approvals for international travel for victim interviews.

persons.name: Darlene Alleyne
persons.role: Legal Assistant, Public Corruption Unit, U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY)
persons.context: The primary correspondent handling travel logistics, booking flights and hotels for the investigation team. She communicates with AUSAs about itinerary changes and refundable ticket requirements.

persons.name: Alex
persons.role: Assistant U.S. Attorney (AUSA), Southern District of New York
persons.context: The main requester of travel arrangements for the Epstein investigation team. He corresponds with Darlene Alleyne about flight options, costs, and the need for refundable tickets for international travel.

persons.name: Alison
persons.role: Team Member / AUSA (inferred), Southern District of New York
persons.context: A colleague on the investigation team whose flight itinerary is used as a cost comparison. Alex seeks to align his travel with her schedule to reduce costs.

persons.name: Maurene
persons.role: Team Member / AUSA (inferred), Southern District of New York
persons.context: Another colleague on the investigation team mentioned in travel coordination emails. Her scheduled flights are also referenced as a cheaper alternative.

persons.name: Edward Tyrrell
persons.role: Supervisory Official (likely AUSA or Section Chief), U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY)
persons.context: The approving official for travel requests related to the Epstein investigation. He grants permission for trips to various locations including Sweden, Los Angeles, and West Palm Beach.

persons.name: Michele Duncan
persons.context: Copied on several travel-related emails, indicating involvement in administrative or oversight functions for the investigation travel.

persons.name: Cynthia Perez
persons.context: Copied on travel coordination emails, suggesting a role in the administrative process for the investigation team's travel.

persons.name: James Bullock
persons.role: U.S. Attorney's Office Staff (likely Budget or Administrative)
persons.context: Mentioned by Darlene Alleyne as being informed about awaiting hotel scheduling, indicating involvement in the travel budgeting or logistics.

connections.description: Alex, an AUSA, works with Darlene Alleyne, a legal assistant, to arrange travel logistics for the Epstein investigation team. Their communication involves itinerary changes, cost approvals, and clarifying requirements for refundable tickets.
Alex requests and receives travel approval from Edward Tyrrell for multiple trips related to the Epstein investigation, indicating a chain of command within the U.S. Attorney's Office.
Both are members of the Epstein investigation team. Alex references Alison's flight schedule to coordinate and reduce travel costs.
Both are members of the Epstein investigation team. Travel plans frequently include Alex, Alison, and/or Maurene for victim interviews.
Darlene copies Michele Duncan on travel emails, indicating collaborative work on administrative tasks for the investigation.
Darlene copies Cynthia Perez on travel emails, suggesting shared responsibility or oversight in the travel approval process.

events.title: Travel to Stockholm for Epstein Investigation Interview
events.description: The investigation team (Alex, Alison, Maurene) travels to Stockholm, Sweden, to conduct an interview related to the Epstein case. The trip involves complex logistics and a focus on securing refundable international flights.

events.title: Travel to Los Angeles for Epstein Investigation Interview
events.description: The team requests permission to travel to Los Angeles for an interview (or interviews) related to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Travel to West Palm Beach for Epstein Investigation Interview
events.description: Alex and Maurene travel to West Palm Beach, Florida, for an interview related to the Epstein investigation, with a request to reserve a conference room.

events.title: Travel to Los Angeles for Victim Interview
events.description: The team (Alex, Alison, and/or Maurene) requests permission to travel to Los Angeles for a victim interview related to the Epstein investigation, with plans to reserve a conference room.

events.title: Approval for Travel to West Palm Beach
events.description: Edward Tyrrell approves a travel request for Alison and Alex to travel to West Palm Beach, Florida, for meetings and interviews related to United States v. Epstein.

keyFacts: The document references the Epstein investigation under case number 2018R01618, described as 'an investigation relating to enticement of minors for sexual activity'.
The U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) team was actively conducting victim interviews in multiple locations (Sweden, Los Angeles, West Palm Beach) as part of the investigation in 2019-2020.
International travel for the investigation required fully refundable flight tickets due to the uncertain nature of witness availability and scheduling.
The email chain reveals internal logistical challenges and cost-consciousness within the U.S. Attorney's Office when arranging last-minute international travel for the investigation.
The primary correspondents are federal prosecutors and staff from the SDNY's Public Corruption Unit, indicating this unit's involvement in the Epstein investigation travel logistics.
